text: Cooksville Station, Mississauga. A future transit super-hub where the GO train will meet the new Hazel McCallion LRT and Dundas Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) will converge, making it a focal point for massive growth.

Cooksville Station, Mississauga. A future transit super-hub where the GO train will meet the new Hazel McCallion LRT and Dundas Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) will converge, making it a focal point for massive growth.
Matching it is a lofty density target of 300 people and jobs per hectare.

However, limitations abound. At its periphery are long-standing neighbourhoods. It is also one of the most physically constrained parts of the city. Termed a “Flood Risk MTSA”, it has over 300 buildings sitting within the Cooksville Creek floodplain.

However, limitations abound. At its periphery are long-standing neighbourhoods. It is also one of the most physically constrained parts of the city. Termed a “Flood Risk MTSA”, it has over 300 buildings sitting within the Cooksville Creek floodplain.
Creating a complete community here means balancing complex technical, social, and regulatory hurdles within a limited footprint.
So, who lives here now?
So, who lives here now?
Cooksville is Mississauga's quintessential gateway. A vibrant, first-stop neighbourhood for nearly 20,000 people, where 1 in 5 residents is a recent arrival.
Two-thirds of its residents are foreign-born (66.5%), and its median age is a youthful 37.4.
It's also a community of renters: over half of all residents rent (50.7%), with most living in high-rise apartments (68.1%).
It's also a community of renters: over half of all residents rent (50.7%), with most living in high-rise apartments (68.1%).
Two-thirds of households are families, alongside a growing number of seniors of whom many live alone.

Public life is centered at the "Four Corners" of Hurontario and Dundas. 

With few formal civic amenities, residents rely on commercial plazas and small parks for daily needs.
Beyond this intersection, amenities quickly thin out, creating a gap between density and daily life.

It is also a socio-economically poorer area. 

Household incomes average about $92,000 per year, starkly lower than the city’s average.
And residents here rely on public transit – more than 57% of the Mississauga average.
Yet the neighbourhood itself is built for the car. Wide arterials and fragmented sidewalks make walking and cycling a challenge.
Adding to the challenge is the land itself.
Adding to the challenge is the land itself.
Many properties east of Hurontario St are Credit Valley Conservation (CVC)-regulated.
Many properties east of Hurontario St are Credit Valley Conservation (CVC)-regulated.
Under CVC rules, development in this area must undergo strict flood mitigation to proceed. It also incentivizes taller growth onto smaller footprints.
Despite the limitations, development is booming.
Despite the limitations, development is booming.
Despite the limitations, development is booming.
Dozens of high-rise projects are in the pipeline, set to transform surface parking lots and aging retail plazas into mixed-use towers.

Developers are engineering their way around the floodplain: elevated podiums, underground storage tanks, and on-site detention systems.    
Expensive, and buried below grade, invisible to the public eye.

Developers are engineering their way around the floodplain: elevated podiums, underground storage tanks, and on-site detention systems.    
Expensive, and buried below grade, invisible to the public eye.

Developers are engineering their way around the floodplain: elevated podiums, underground storage tanks, and on-site detention systems.    
Expensive, and buried below grade, invisible to the public eye.
Some civic infrastructure, including the Cooksville Community Hub co-located with the TL Kennedy Secondary School, has been planned.
A new skyline is coming to fruition, driven by transit investment and the city’s growth targets.
A new skyline is coming to fruition, driven by transit investment and the city’s growth targets.
What happens if we continue this way?
Accounting for floodplain considerations and stable neighbourhoods, these are the parcels most eligible for development.
Growth becomes concentrated on a handful of underused commercial and industrial lots.
Growth becomes concentrated on a handful of underused commercial and industrial lots.
Growth becomes concentrated on a handful of underused commercial and industrial lots.
The default is towers on podiums – a built form tried and tested to generate density effectively.
But does this create a livable neighbourhood?

Crucial infrastructure is not keeping pace.     
The Cooksville Community Hub, while planned, needs funding. Other cultural amenities are virtually non-existent.
Local parks are small and discontinuous, and few institutional sites exist to anchor future population growth.
New towers cluster on fragmented lots, with density pushed further up to offset costly flood mitigation measures.
Without early investment in civic infrastructure, Cooksville risks becoming a collection of towers: dense but socially thin.
Without early investment in civic infrastructure, Cooksville risks becoming a collection of towers: dense but socially thin.
**Is this really the best we can build?**
The challenge isn’t just accommodating density. It’s catalyzing it to create connected and amenity-rich communities where residents can flourish.
Here’s how we could do it.
Our approach starts by adopting the current strategy for *where* to build: underused parcels like aging plazas and surface parking lots.
This leaves stable residential neighbourhoods mostly untouched.
Next, let’s reframe the floodplain restriction.
Next, let’s reframe the floodplain restriction.
What happens when we approach floodplain mitigation as a public realm opportunity? This means moving beyond simply burying water tanks underground.
By weaving (less expensive!) green infrastructure across sites, we create daily spaces for social connection: new pathways, parks, and adaptive landscapes that guide future development.
The more developers who adopt this strategy, the larger the green network, amplifying benefits for the entire community.
Now let’s turn our attention to build for the life that’s already here.
Now let’s turn our attention to build for the life that’s already here.
Data shows most residents enjoy an engaged urban life, including concerts, restaurants, fitness classes, sports, and galleries. The current landscape doesn’t reflect that.
In a growing community, social infrastructure and third places are just as important as housing.
The optimized plan focuses on creating spaces for gathering - integrating community theatres, youth centres, and libraries directly into new mixed-use blocks.
Finally, let’s build housing for how people actually live.
Two-thirds of households are families, yet the average new proposal allocates around 70% of new units as 1-bedrooms.

The market is sending an undeniable signal too. Demand for 1-bedrooms is low, with supply outpacing demand. Meanwhile, larger units are outperforming them, with 2.5 times the sales volume – many selling above asking price.
Building what the community needs is the obvious direction.
This means prioritizing units with two or more bedrooms for families and multi-generational households.
This means prioritizing units with two or more bedrooms for families and multi-generational households.
This is also a more efficient way to build. Larger, family-sized units house more people in a smaller total footprint.
Think of it this way: 3 people in a 3-bedroom share 1 kitchen. 3 people in 3 separate 1-bedrooms require 3 separate kitchens.
It allows for a reduction in extreme height. Towers can be shorter, and more mid-rise buildings can be introduced to create active, human-scaled street fronts.
In this vision, density is achieved through a connected urban fabric - a mix of housing forms for how people actually live.
Social infrastructure, from the community hub to vibrant local shops, is woven into a landscape where green corridors double as flood protection and public parks.
By treating housing, amenities, and water as one integrated system, the plan shifts from managing constraints to building a complete, resilient, and connected Cooksville.
